Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Seed defense syndromes of tropical forest trees: emergent properties of seed dormancy, defense and microbial interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Over the past 35 years, a robust theory of plant defenses has been developed to explain why plant species vary in the toxicity and physical toughness of their vegetative tissues. Application of this theory has broadened our understanding of plant-herbivore interactions, yielding new insights into plant ecology and evolution. This project will now extend the theory to cover defenses of seeds against fungi in the soil. Seeds have only a limited capacity to adjust resource acquisition and allocation to track a changing environment or to combat individual threats. Fungi that attack and can kill seeds should therefore create strong selection on suites of characteristics, or seed defense syndromes. This project will quantify the chemical and physical defenses of seeds of 18 tree species that exhibit a broad range of seed traits and germination behavior in lowland tropical forest in Panama. Experiments will determine the time course of seed survival, the efficacy of defenses at different times following dispersal onto the soil, and the ways in which particular defenses correlate with others to form syndromes of seed defensive traits. The study will offer a new perspective on the ecological and evolutionary importance of seed dormancy and a first step towards formalizing seed defense syndromes for an array of ecologically important plants.

The project will provide unique, cross-disciplinary training in tropical ecology, molecular biology, and fungal biology at the undergraduate, graduate, and post-doctoral levels and will support research and publication by students from the United States and Latin America. Research protocols and data sets will be posted on a bilingual, project website, and results will be disseminated through the public outreach programs of the Mycological Herbarium of the University of Arizona.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tropical rainforests represent some of the most diverse biomes on earth. Pioneer trees -- those tree species that colonize forest edges and gaps -- are important in tropical forest ecology because they rapidly occupy cleared areas and facilitate the later establishment of diverse biological communities. Pioneer trees often produce small seeds that, remarkably, can persist in tropical soils for months or years. These 'soil seed banks' are intriguing because they are rich in seed-infecting microbes, yet seeds persist and germinate effectively.

The aim of our study was to understand how seed traits interact with microbial communities in the establishment of pioneer trees. We conducted a large field experiment in Panama in which we placed seeds of 18 species of tropical trees into small mesh bags, and placed the bags in the forest in five common gardens. We collected seeds at intervals of up to 24 months and evaluated seed integrity, germinability, and microbial infection.

Our project has shown that some fungi are important in helping seeds germinate. Others protect against disease. Others still can have a negative effect on some tree species, but can be beneficial for others. Our data suggest a strong effect of tree species on fungal communities -- the identity of the tree species is more important than the duration of burial (how long seeds are in the soil) or their location.

Overall this project has supported the training of numerous young scientists ranging from high school students to postdocs. It has fostered educational outreach with K-12 teachers and supported workshops in which high school students have gained hands-on experience in molecular biology, microbiology, and plant ecology. Results have been presented in national and international venues and are the basis for diverse and numerous publications.

The intellectual merit of our work is that it contributes to a new understanding of the scale of biodiversity in tropical forests, and the importance of soil microbes and fungi in influencing the establishment of pioneer trees. The assays and analytical pipelines we have developed can contribute widely to studies of seed biology and plant ecology, and are extendable to sustainable agriculture and related applications. This project has resulted in the release of large data sets integrating molecular sequence data (DNA sequences) with accompanying ecological data, and generated a major new biodiversity collection that is unique in its coverage of seed-associated microbes.

The broader impacts of our work include extensive training of students and postdocs, outreach to the public in educational and other venues, integration of project information into large university courses, and distribution of the findings of our work in electronic and published formats.
